Given $a \neq 0,$ solve for $x$ in
\[\begin{vmatrix} x + a & x  & x \\ x & x + a & x \\ x & x & x + a \end{vmatrix} = 0.\]Give your answer in terms of $a.$
inference:
Expanding the determinant, we have
\begin{align*} &(x + a)(x + a)(x) + x(x)(x) + x(x)(x) \\ &- x(x)(x + a) - x(x + a)(x) - (x + a)(x)(x) \\ &= x(x + a)^2 + x^3 + x^3 - x^3(x + a) - x^2(x + a) - x^2(x + a) \\ &= x(x^2 + 2ax + a^2) + 2x^3 - x^4 - ax^3 - 2x^2(x + a) \\ &= x^3 + 2ax^2 + a^2x + 2x^3 - x^4 - ax^3 - 2x^3 - 2ax^2 \\ &= -x^4 + x^3 + a^2x \\ &= -x^4 + x^3 + a^2x \\ &= -x(x^3 - x^2 - a^2) = 0. \end{align*}Since $x \ne 0,$ we have $x^3 - x^2 - a^2 = 0.$
We can factor this cubic polynomial as $x(x^2 - x - a^2) = 0.$  Thus, $x = 0$ or $x^2 - x - a^2 = 0.$  The quadratic formula gives
\[ x = \frac{1 \pm \sqrt{1 + 4a^2}}{2}. \]Therefore, the solutions are $x = 0,$ $x = \frac{1 + \sqrt{1 + 4a^2}}{2},$ and $x = \frac{1 - \sqrt{1 + 4a^2}}{2}.$

Final Answer: $\boxed{\frac{1 \pm \sqrt{1 + 4a^2}}{2}}$
ground_truth:
We can expand the determinant as follows:
\begin{align*}
\begin{vmatrix} x + a & x  & x \\ x & x + a & x \\ x & x & x + a \end{vmatrix} &= (x + a) \begin{vmatrix} x + a & x \\ x & x + a \end{vmatrix} - x \begin{vmatrix} x & x \\ x & x + a \end{vmatrix} + x \begin{vmatrix} x & x + a \\ x & x \end{vmatrix} \\
&= (x + a)((x + a)^2 - x^2) - x(x(x + a) - x^2) + x(x^2 - (x + a)(x)) \\
&= 3a^2 x + a^3 \\
&= a^2 (3x + a).
\end{align*}Hence, $x = \boxed{-\frac{a}{3}}.$
